title: American_Top_40_1978_August_12th
description:
American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Casey answers the question, "In the rock era, has there ever been a recording act who achieved Billboard's number one record-of-the-year more than once?" Casey says it's happened twice.

Steve Martin (The Jerk, Little Shop Of Horrors, Pink Panther) is at number 17 with his hit "King Tut."

One group in the countdown has a member who once scored points with his girlfriend by making a recording star out of her little brother. He wrote a number one song for the kid and Casey gives the details.

Two songs in the countdown are by an act that comes from a family which (as of August 1978) has cumulatively occupied the number one spot on the singles chart more than any other family in the rock era; 34 weeks (nearly eight months).

One listener wants to know, "What recording act had the record that reached the top ten the fastest during the rock era?" Casey lists three acts that debuted on the top 40 in the top 10, and one of those did it three times.
